title: Ticket #6721: Segfault by the ClassAd python-wrapper
description:
A user on htcondor-users reports a segfault when using the python bindings with python 3 as follows: 

       Python 3.6.5 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Apr  6 2018, 13:39:56)


       [GCC 4.8.2 20140120 (Red Hat 4.8.2-15)] on linux


       >>> import htcondor, classad


       >>> coll  = htcondor.Collector()


       >>> schedd= htcondor.Schedd(coll.locate(htcondor.DaemonTypes.Schedd))


       >>> print([(k,v) for k,v in schedd.query()[0].items()])


       Segmentation fault (core dumped)

The user investigated the problem and passes on the following useful explanation and potential solution:

    The root of this SEGFAULT is that the `items` method of `ClassAdWrapper` returns invalid references to its child objects. A ClassAd object usually contains some objects of nontrivial type, such as `classad.ExprTree`, which are destroyed when their parent is garbage-collected by the python runtime. Therefore trying to access such objects results in memory access violation (SEGFAULT). Here is the code section responsible for it: https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/blob/3c73f7c8bcb9d4b99793cd3bc97251639e18b99d/src/python-bindings/classad.cpp#L993

    This is a python3-only problem because the `items` method of python 3 object returns an `iterator` instead of a list of tuples.

    The proposed solution is to properly transform any non-trivial child object of `ClassAdWrapper` into a python object (with its own reference counter) so that the runtime can garbage collected them correctly.

2018-Aug-16 16:02:41 by jpatton:
J. Karpel is running into what we believe is a related problem:

    This works: 

schedd = htcondor.Schedd()
with schedd.transaction() as txn:
    submit.queue(txn, 5)

    This does not: 

with htcondor.Schedd().transaction() as txn:
    submit.queue(txn, 5)

    It complains that the transaction isn't active. [...] My only guess is that the transaction doesn't have a reference to the schedd object, so if you don't manually give it a reference the schedd object gets cleaned up before the transaction executes, leaving the transaction dangling.

2018-Aug-16 16:19:51 by edquist:
That makes sense.

In the broken case, the temporary schedd object is destroyed (well, it goes out of scope anyway) before submit.queue() is executed.

But, i bet you could do something like: 

with htcondor.Schedd() as schedd:
    with schedd.transaction() as txn:
        submit.queue(txn, 5)

2018-Aug-16 16:23:43 by edquist:
Or, if you find with statements offensive, i suspect the following could work, as i think temporaries are supposed to stay in scope / not get destroyed for the lifetime of the whole expression: 

submit.queue(htcondor.Schedd().transaction(), 5)

2019-Jul-08 16:03:01 by johnkn:
Notes:

Some discussion between TJ, ToddM and Josh lead two some hypothesis about the problem and proposed solutions.

In effect, a c++ ExprTree that is owned by a c++ Classad is freed when the Classad is freed. But there are situations where the Bindings ClassAsWrapper can have it's ref count go to zero (and possibly be freed) while a python ExprTreeHolder object that points to an ExprTree within that classad still has a non-zero reference count.

This appears to be much more likely with Python3.

We discussed a few possible solutions, all are variations of holding a reference on The ClassAdWrapper while the ExprTreeHolder is alive.

  1. The ExprTreeHolde=r could hold a reference to the =ClassAdWrapper when it is fetched from there.
  2. The ClassAdWrapper could keep an exhaustive list of ExprTreeHolders that it has handed out, and keep itself alive as long as any of them are alive.
  3. An ExprTreeHolder class could be changed to be either a free ExprTree, or a ClassAdWrapper + attribute-name

It was suggested that fixing this before we switch to PyBind11 may not be a good use of time, since we may have to do the reference counting in a different way with PyBind11.

2019-Jul-08 16:04:41 by johnkn:
To fix the fix the first problem mentioned in this ticket, the bindings AttrItemIter class needs to hold a reference on the ClassAdWrapper it refers to.

2019-Jul-09 08:13:52 by bbockelm:
Note that the python bindings already do appropriate lifetime management -- anytime an ExprTree is handed out as a result of __getitem__, the return value policy ensures the ExprTree keeps a reference to the parent ClassAdWrapper.

See here:

https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/blob/master/src/python-bindings/classad_module_impl.cpp#L499

and the implementation of the return value policy:

https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/blob/master/src/python-bindings/classad_expr_return_policy.h

(note that this special relationship is only done when a ExprTree or ClassAdWrapper is returned ... things such as strings or ints have no internal reference back to the ClassAd).

The problem here is, of course, that there are callsites where the lifetime isn't declared. Scanning through (https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/blob/master/src/python-bindings/classad_module_impl.cpp#L556), I think this is missing for get(), setdefault(), and the various iterators (items(), keys(), etc).

The good news is this is approximately a one-line change for the relevant callsites. This also appears completely orthogonal to the move to pybind11 (which uses the same model).

2019-Jul-09 08:14:54 by bbockelm:
Note: the missing lifetime declaration is the same root problem as the issue with the transaction method above. There's probably other cases in Python.
